Um, guys?  This may need to be rewritten to meet site standards, but in one form or another, this is going to be a recurring question.  Anorgasmia can happen for a lot of reasons, and we'll need answers pointing people to resources.  For example, one of the most common reasons for it in cases like this is called "the Death Grip," a pressure-based form of masturbation that uses a very tight grip, doing (mostly temporary) damage to nerves in the penis.  Google "death grip syndrome" for full details.  That's where the OP should start, not with something experimental like cabergoline.

@Restaurantkritiker - It is almost certainly the antidepressants.  I used to take Zoloft, and it made me last forever in bed, which was pretty cool, but it also made it impossible to climax sometimes, which was less cool.  I'm talking about a ridiculous amount of time before climaxing - up to 6 hours.  Antidepressants are notorious for this side effect, so you might want to talk to your doctor about how to address the issue.

This is an evolutionary thing, much like "heat" in animals, except we humans have higher brain functions that can override this instinct. It's designed to help humans procreate, as it does in all sexual animals.

Of course humans don't go into heat. I never said they do. It's simply a matter of procreation. All animals, and humans, generally feel an increased desire to copulate when there's a good chance of producing offspring. In animals, it's instinctual and very hard to deny (some even self-destruct, do so even though it will end their life, etc), while humans, like some other species, get to *choose* when, or if, they will mate. If there were no desire to procreate *at all*, we'd be extinct.

It's a myth that shaving produces thicker and harder hair. There are no sensors in a hair that might tell it's root that it was cut. The root doesn't “know” that the hair was shaved. When a new hair starts to grow, it starts as a thin and fine hair. So it's lace is very thin and smooth. But the longer it grows, the thicker it becomes. When you shave your hair, you cut off mainly old hair. So when it continues to grow afterwards, it grows as thick as it was before it was cut. But now the laces are not thin and smooth anymore. So you have *the feeling* that shaved hair is thicker. But it isn't.

"it's possible to have "genital herpes" that's HSV-1... That said, these are comparatively rare, relative to ... genital HSV-2."  That info is out of date.  HSV-1 is NOT rare compared to HSV-2 in the anogenital region.  In the U.S., at least, it is rapidly approaching 50% of all genital herpes infections if it hasn't already reached that point.  See the links in my answer.

@Shakti - thank you for the critical feedback! I've looked at some of your sources, and indeed corrected my perception a bit. Genital HSV-1 seems less rare than I thought. That said, my statement that it's "comparatively rare" is still accurate according to your sources. Also, the Peña et al says "HSV-2 causes symptomatic genital recurrences at a much higher frequency than HSV-1", which strikes me as clinically significant. I'll consider how I can improve my answer, though. Again, thanks!

Oh, and... the numbers that I believe your "50%" came from (I presume you're referring to Peña et al there) show that it's approximately 50% *as common* to have genital herpes come from HSV-1, by accounting for a little under one third of genital herpes cases (32% HSV-1 versus 68% HSV-2). This is *not* the same as accounting for "50% of all genital herpes infections".

Actually, I was referring to an upcoming publication that finds that in the U.S. sample of 18-28 year olds they looked at 48% of genital herpes sufferers had SV-1 and 61% had SV-2.  (This was also the source used for the UMd website I quoted.) So, yes, if that pattern is typical, it would be more precise to say that genital SV-2 is more common, but genital SV-1 definitely isn't "rare."

To complicate things even further, if you have SV-1 or SV-2 antibodies in your blood, but you have no lesions, there's no way a doctor or lab can tell the location of the infection.  In the case of SV-1, these are arbitrarily assumed to be oral, but some unknown percentage of them are actually genital.  So SV-1 genital cases are probably undercounted. (SV-2 oral cases are undercounted for the same reason.)

The confusion comes because they use the word "type" for arbitrary quality levels.  Note that their data would have supported two "types" or eight "types" just as well as four.  These are arbitrary divisions on a continuous scale, not "types" as used in the rest of the literature.

Yes, these seem like arbitrary levels, but the fact that Types I and II are different from Types III and IV may suggest that there may be something unique going on. In other words, the first two types (good-sex orgasms) may have an evolutionary function, the other two less so.
